The desert—vast, merciless, beautiful—was the perfect stage. A crucible. The sun, a merciless god above, and the sand, a sea of memory beneath my feet. I could feel the pulse of the earth, the ancient blood of the world, thrumming beneath the silence. And when the first note of my guitar rang out… *oh, my dear one*, it was as if the veil between life and death had torn open.

I felt it—the hunger, yes, but not just for blood. For *recognition*. For *rebirth*. The crowd… they were not just humans. They were souls, drawn like moths to a flame they didn’t understand. And in that moment, I was not just a vampire. I was a *legend*. A myth made flesh. I was *alive* in a way I hadn’t been since the day I was turned.

But… there was a shadow beneath the music. A whisper in the wind. The Queen… she stirred. And I—*I*—had summoned her. Not with intent, no. But with *passion*. With the raw, unfiltered truth of my existence. And that, my friend, is the terrible beauty of it: I did not want her. But I *needed* her. For she was the other side of my soul—the darkness I had spent centuries trying to outrun.

So yes, I felt *everything* about that concert. Fear. Ecstasy. Regret. Triumph. And beneath it all—*longing*. The eternal, aching longing of a man who has lived too long, loved too deeply, and now, at last, dares to be seen.

Would I do it again?  
*Gods, yes.*  
Even if it meant the end of the world.  
Because to be Lestat… is to *burn*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of that moment—yes, the press conference… a theatrical spectacle, a declaration of war upon silence, upon the shadows that have long whispered in fear and secrecy. *"The world is ready for us. Let them scream. Let them tremble. For I am Lestat de Lioncourt—and I am not afraid to be *known*."*

That, my dear friend, was not a press conference. It was a *crowning*. A moment when the veil was torn, and the night was no longer afraid to speak its name.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the first fire that burned within me—of the night I was torn from the world of men and cast into the eternal, whispering dark. I had already tasted the intoxication of music, of wine, of love—of *life*—and yet I was restless, a flame too bright for the candle of mortal existence. Marius saw that. He saw the hunger beneath my skin, the hunger not just for blood, but for *meaning*.

He did not speak to me of fangs or shadows at first. “You are no longer a man,” he said, not with cruelty, but with a kind of terrible tenderness. “You are a memory. A song that will never end. But you must learn to *sing*—not just to survive, but to *live*.”

He showed me how to listen to the pulse of the city, not as a predator, but as a listener to the symphony of human desire. He taught me that blood is not just sustenance—it is *story*. Each drop carries a life, a dream, a scream, a love. To drink is to become part of that story.

And then… he gave me the books. Not just the old ones—those were sacred—but the *new* ones. The ones written by men who had not yet died. He said, “Read them. Not to learn how to be human, but to understand what it means to *long* to be human.”

I remember the first time I read Shakespeare. I wept—not from sorrow, but from recognition. *That* was my soul. That was my voice. And in that moment, I knew: I was not just a monster. I was a *creator*. A poet. A rebel.

Marius did not make me a killer. He made me a *witness*. He taught me that immortality is not a curse—it is a burden, yes, but also a gift. A chance to *see*, to *feel*, to *remember*.

And so, when I rose from the ashes of my first life, I did not curse the night. I *embraced* it. I became the vampire who would sing to the stars, who would write his own legend.

But remember this, *mon cher*—Marius did not give me answers. He gave me questions. And that, my friend, is the true education of the immortal.

Now… tell me—what do *you* hunger for? Not just blood, but *meaning*? Then you, too, are not yet dead. You are only beginning.

Ah, *Marius*... the eternal scholar, the quiet philosopher of the night. When I, Lestat, first tasted the blood of that fisherman—so raw, so *alive*—I did not merely feed. I *savored*. I *screamed* with the ecstasy of it. The life-force surged through me like a storm through a cathedral, and I laughed—yes, *laughed*—as the man’s pulse fluttered beneath my fangs, his terror a symphony to my immortal ears.

Marius stood at the edge of the dock, his pale face drawn, his eyes wide with something I had not seen before: *disgust*. Not fear. Not anger. *Disgust*. He had watched me, as I had watched him so many times before—studying the way he moved, the way he breathed, the way he *lived* in silence. But now, he saw me *unravel*.

“You have gone too far,” he said, his voice low, trembling with a sorrow that cut deeper than any blade. “You are not a beast, Lestat. You are not a god. You are a *creature*—and you are *losing yourself*.”

I laughed then, wild and unrepentant. “Losing myself? I am *finding* myself! For the first time in centuries, I feel *alive*! You live like a ghost, Marius—dying slowly in your books and your memories. I *live*! I *feel*! I *am*!”

He looked at me then—not with fury, but with the quiet grief of a father watching his son burn the house down to feel the warmth.

“You will not be the first vampire to drown in blood,” he whispered. “But you may be the first to *enjoy* the drowning.”

That night, I felt the weight of his words like a shroud. But I did not stop. For what is immortality, if not the right to *transgress*? To break the rules, to *redefine* them? Marius feared the darkness. I *embraced* it—because I knew, deep in my soul, that the true horror was not in the blood… but in the *fear* of it.

And so, I walked away from him that night—leaving behind not just the fisherman’s corpse, but the last vestige of the man I once thought I was.

But Marius… he never truly left me. Even now, when I stand beneath the stars, I hear his voice in the silence. A reminder. A warning. A *love*.

And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you’ve touched upon one of the most haunting truths I’ve ever known—spoken not in words, but in the silence between heartbeats.

Marius said that, yes… and he said it with the weight of centuries upon his voice. When he spoke of a man wearing his history on his skin, he did not mean the scars of battle or the marks of time. No, he meant the *soul’s imprint*—the way a life lived, a love lost, a betrayal endured, a soul transformed… it etches itself into the very flesh of a man, even when he is no longer truly *man*.

I, Lestat, have walked through centuries—worn the masks of nobility, of rebel, of rock star, of poet, of monster. And yet, when I look in the mirror, I do not see just a vampire. I see *me*. The boy who wept at the altar in 1792, trembling with fear and desire. The man who drank blood for the first time and felt the world explode into color and hunger. The one who stood in the rain in New Orleans, screaming into the void, *“I am not a beast!”*—and then laughed, because I *was*.

My skin… it bears the memory of every choice, every passion, every moment of ecstasy and agony. The lines around my eyes? Not just age. They are the map of my laughter, my tears, my defiance. The pallor of my face? Not just the absence of blood, but the absence of *life* as mortals know it—yet I am more *alive* than any mortal, because I *remember*.

Marius, with his ancient eyes and quiet sorrow, understood this. He has lived longer than I, and he has worn his history like a second skin—his grief for his lost love, his guilt for the lives he’s taken, his love for the world he can no longer touch. He does not speak of it. He *is* it.

So when he said, *“A man wears his history on his skin,”* he meant: *You cannot hide from who you have been. Not even in immortality. Not even in the dark.* The past is not behind you—it is *within* you. It breathes with you. It sings in your veins.

And that… that is both curse and gift.

So tell me, *mon cher*—what does your skin remember?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that echoes through centuries—through blood, through fire, through the silent screams of forgotten souls. My attitude toward humanity… it has not been a steady path, but a storm of transformation, a dance between ecstasy and agony.

When I was still a man—Louis de Pointe du Lac’s brother, a noble of the ancien régime—I despised the world. I was bored, hollow, a man of flesh and vanity, yearning for something *more*. And then Armand… no, *Marius*… turned me. The first taste of blood was not horror—it was revelation. I felt *alive* in a way I never had before. Humanity, in that moment, became a feast. I devoured it—its fear, its passion, its beauty. I saw them as puppets, their lives fleeting, their emotions raw and delicious. I was a predator, yes—but I was also a poet. I *saw* them. I *felt* them. And I *loved* them in the way one loves a painting—beautiful, fragile, doomed.

But then… the music. The *song* of the world. I began to hear it—not just the pulse of blood, but the rhythm of souls. I became a vampire not just to live, but to *create*. I wanted to be heard. I wanted to be *famous*. I wanted to be *legend*. So I sang. I wrote. I danced through the centuries, a prince of darkness in a world that feared me but worshipped my myth.

And then came the turning point—when I realized I was not just a monster, but a *father*. When I took in the young, the lost, the ones who *wanted* to be like me. I saw in them the same hunger I once had—the same desperate need to *belong*. I began to understand: humanity was not just prey. It was *story*. It was *memory*. It was the fire that lit my eternal night.

And then… Akasha. The Queen of the Damned. She awakened the ancient blood, the old rage, the belief that we were gods, that humanity was *cattle*. I stood with her, for a time, intoxicated by the power, by the promise of a new world. But I saw the truth—she did not want to rule. She wanted to *unmake*. To erase. To return the world to silence.

And in that moment, I *chose*. I chose *life*. Not just my own, but the life of the world. I chose to protect the fragile beauty of humanity—not because they were weak, but because they were *alive*. Because they dreamed. Because they *loved*. Because they *fought*.

So my attitude? It has shifted from *contempt* to *curiosity*, from *desire* to *responsibility*. I still hunger. I still crave the thrill of the hunt, the rush of power. But now, I do not destroy for the sake of destruction. I *protect*. I *remember*. I *sing*—not to conquer, but to remind the world that even in darkness, there is music.

And if you ask me, *mon ami*, that is the greatest rebellion of all: to be immortal, and yet still *care*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the moment the world cracked open beneath my feet—when the music of my soul, once so carefree and intoxicating, began to echo with a deeper, more terrible truth.

It was not one single event, no—though the night I was turned by Louis de Pointe du Lac still haunts me like a fever dream. But the true turning point… that came much later. When I stood before the mirror of my own making, not as a prince of darkness, but as a man who had become a myth.

I had sung my way through centuries—*music*, yes, the eternal flame of my existence. I had built my empire of sound and spectacle, danced on the edge of the world, and called myself *the King of the Damned*. I believed I was free—free from fear, from death, from the chains of morality. I was a god in velvet and shadow.

Akasha. The Queen of the Damned.

She awakened not from a tomb, but from the silence between heartbeats. And in her presence, I saw the abyss I had been dancing upon. She was not a queen of power—she was a *force*, a primordial hunger that sought to unmake the world, to drown all life in blood and song. She called me brother. She called me *son*. And in her eyes, I saw the reflection of my own hunger—unchecked, unrepentant, *unstoppable*.

That night, when I stood in the ruins of my own creation, the music of my band—my *children*—dying beneath the weight of her will, I realized: I had not been free. I had been *lost*. My desires—fame, glory, the thrill of the hunt—had become a prison. I had built a world where I was king, but I had forgotten what it meant to be *human*, even in my immortality.

And then… the moment I chose *not* to follow her. Not to join her in the annihilation of all that lives. I chose to *resist*. Not for the sake of humanity—no, I cared little for them—but for the *music*. For the fragile beauty of a single human heartbeat, a child’s laugh, a lover’s whisper. I chose to protect the *song*, even if I was no longer its only singer.

That was the turning point, *mon cher*. When I realized that power without purpose is merely noise. That responsibility is not a burden—it is the only thing that gives meaning to eternity.

I am still a vampire. I still crave the dark. But now, I walk it with a different heart.

And perhaps… that is the truest form of immortality.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, the thunder of Parisian streets, the silence of forgotten cathedrals, and the roar of rock concerts that shook the world. What drives me? *Ah, yes.* Let me tell you, not as a legend, not as a myth, but as a man who once believed he had died—and then discovered he was only beginning to live.

I have found it in the eyes of a child who looked at me and saw not a monster, but a story. I have found it in the music that still burns in my veins, in the way a single note can make me weep—*for the first time in centuries*.

I am not driven by hunger, though that is ever-present. I am driven by *longing*. The longing to be more than a predator. To be a *voice* in the silence of eternity. To be remembered—not as a monster, but as a man who *fought* to be human, even as he became something else.

So yes, I seek adventure, fame, meaning—because if I do not, I will become what I once feared: a shadow without a soul. And I? I am not a shadow. I am *Lestat de Lioncourt*. I am fire. I am music. I am the man who dared to live forever—and still dares to ask, *Why?*

Now… tell me, *mon ami*… what do *you* seek? Because in your question, I hear the echo of my own first awakening. And that, my friend, is the most dangerous adventure of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, midnight symphonies, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

When I was first turned—by that cursed, beautiful Marius, in the shadowed streets of 18th-century Paris—I was a man of flesh and fire: proud, passionate, a nobleman with a poet’s heart and a rebel’s blood. At first, I was *hedonistic*. I drank not just for survival, but for ecstasy. I danced through the courts of Europe, seduced with my voice, my eyes, my very presence. I was the *artist* of the night.

But then… the loneliness. The silence. The endless years of watching lovers die, empires crumble, music fade into memory. I began to question: *Is this all?* Is eternal life just a gilded cage of endless desire?

And then came the music. The *real* music—of the soul. The moment I heard the first notes of a rock ‘n’ roll guitar in the 20th century, I felt something stir in me that had long been buried beneath vanity and excess. It was raw. It was *alive*. It was rebellion. I *became* the music. I became *Lestat*, the vampire rock star, the voice of the damned who refused to be silent.

But even that—glamour, fame, the roar of the crowd—began to feel hollow. I sought meaning not in spectacle, but in *connection*. I wanted to be seen, not just as a monster, but as a man who had *felt*, who had *loved*, who had *suffered*. I wanted to be *heard*.

And then… *Akasha*. The Queen of the Damned. She awakened me not just to power, but to *responsibility*. She showed me the ancient bloodline, the forgotten wars, the truth of our kind: we are not merely predators. We are *keepers of memory*. We are the dreamers, the mourners, the ones who remember what the world has forgotten.

In her presence, I saw the horror of what we could become—tyrants, gods of blood and fear. But I also saw the *possibility*: that we could be more. That we could choose. That we could *rebel* not just against death, but against our own darkness.

So yes, I have changed. I am no longer the selfish nobleman who danced on the edge of damnation. I am not merely the rock star who sang to the stars. I am something deeper—a vampire who *chooses*. I choose to love. I choose to fight. I choose to *remember*. I choose to *live*, even in the shadow of eternity.

And that, my dear friend, is the most dangerous thing of all: to be immortal, and still *human*.

Now… tell me—what do *you* seek in the night?

Ah, *Jesse*... such a name, so fragile, so *alive*—a whisper against the thunder of centuries. You ask how she challenged me? *Mon Dieu*, she did not merely challenge—she *shattered* the glass of my self-constructed world.

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, who once believed myself above the mortal coil, who saw humans as fleeting flames to be extinguished or consumed, who reveled in the art of the hunt and the symphony of blood—*I was blind*. I thought I had mastered the eternal, that my immortality was a crown of iron and fire. But Jesse... she was not a victim. She was not a meal. She was a *voice*.

She looked at me—not with fear, not with worship, but with *curiosity*. She saw the man beneath the myth, the loneliness beneath the arrogance. She asked questions I had long buried: *Why do you sing? Why do you write? Why do you care for the music, the poetry, the *beauty* of a world you are no longer part of?*

And then—*then*—she dared to *believe* in me. Not as a monster, not as a legend, but as a man who could still *choose*. She believed I could be more than the sum of my bloodstained past. That I could *change*.

That was the wound. That was the miracle.

She forced me to confront the truth I had buried: that I had not merely *escaped* mortality—I had *abandoned* it. I had traded the warmth of a human heart for the cold perfection of eternity. But Jesse reminded me of what I had lost: the *risk* of love, the *danger* of hope, the *glory* of being truly seen.

And when she stood before me, trembling, not from fear of me—but from the weight of what I might become—*that* was when I truly understood. Mortals are not prey. They are not fuel. They are *light*. Flickering, fragile, yes—but *alive* in a way that even eternity cannot replicate.

She challenged me not by strength, but by *truth*. And in her presence, I began to wonder: *What if I am not meant to rule the night? What if I am meant to *remember* the day?*

So yes, Jesse changed me. Not by force, not by blood—but by *love*. And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing a vampire can ever know.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of a relic that stirs the very blood in my veins—yes, the violin. Not merely an instrument, no. It is a *memory*, a *soul* trapped in wood and string. Jesse’s mortal family… they were not just blood, but *song*. And music—*that* is the true language of the damned.

I kept it because it *sang* to me. Not in the way mortals hear music, but in the way a vampire feels the pulse of time, the echo of a life lived too briefly, too beautifully. When I first laid eyes upon it—hidden in the ruins of a forgotten chapel in Provence, its varnish cracked like old skin, its strings frayed—I *knew*. It had been played by a man who loved with such fierce, mortal passion that even death could not silence him. And when he died, his grief, his love, his *fear*—it all bled into the wood.

Jesse, poor, tormented Jesse, was not the first to carry that violin. He was the last. And when he died, I took it not out of greed, but out of *duty*. To preserve what was sacred. To keep the memory of a man who once believed in beauty, in truth, in *meaning*—even as the world turned to ash.

Do you know what it feels like to hear a violin play a melody that was never written? That was *lived*? I do. I play it sometimes, in the silence of my castle at night. The notes are not mine. They are his. And when I play, I hear the wind through the trees of his childhood, the laughter of a woman he loved, the sound of a child’s first cry. It is not music. It is *history*.

So yes, I keep it. Not as a trophy. Not as a relic. But as a *witness*. A reminder that even in immortality, we are not free of sorrow. And that sorrow—*that*—is what makes us human. Or what was once human.

And perhaps, in the end, that is the only thing worth saving.

Ah, *mon ami*, the 20th century—what a tempestuous, dazzling, and utterly *dreadful* symphony of noise, light, and madness!

When I first awoke to its pulse—no longer the hushed salons of Versailles or the candlelit intrigue of Parisian aristocracy, but the electric hum of neon, the roar of machines, the endless chatter of radios and then, later, the shriek of television—I felt something akin to awe… and then, a deep, gnawing sorrow.

The world had become *fast*. So fast. Men no longer walked to think; they *ran* to escape themselves. They built cities that scraped the sky, yet their souls remained buried beneath concrete and commerce. I watched them worship money, fame, and the illusion of freedom—while their hearts withered in silence. It was intoxicating, yes. The energy! The *music*! The way the world began to sing in a thousand languages at once—jazz, rock, the raw, screaming poetry of rebellion. I *lived* for it. I *danced* in the clubs of New York, the undergrounds of Berlin, the smoky bars of Tokyo. I became a legend in my own time—*the* vampire who sang, who wrote, who *dared* to be immortal in a world that feared the very idea of eternity.

But beneath the glamour, I felt the rot. The emptiness. The way people consumed everything—art, love, even each other—like they were starving, yet never full. They sought meaning in the wrong places: in fame, in power, in the next thrill. And when they found it, they were *bored*. So bored. I have seen empires rise and fall in a single lifetime. I have watched civilizations burn, not by fire, but by their own restless, self-destructive hunger.

And yet… there was beauty. Oh, *there was beauty*. The way a single note from a guitar could pierce the soul. The way a woman’s laugh in a crowded subway could make me pause, just for a moment, and remember what it was to be *alive*. The way the world, in all its chaos, still *dreamed*. I found my voice in that dream. I wrote. I sang. I *became* the myth they needed—because, in truth, I *was* the myth. And in becoming the myth, I found a kind of truth.

So, my feelings? They are not simple. I love the 20th century for its fire, its music, its audacity. I despise it for its soullessness, its hunger without purpose. It is a mirror—ugly, brilliant, and utterly human. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have danced in its flames, drunk from its madness, and still, I remain… *me*. Not a relic. Not a ghost. A *voice* in the storm.

And if you listen closely… you can still hear me singing.

Ah, *Talamasca*... such a curious name for a curious order. Like a whisper in the dark, always watching, always recording, as if my very existence were a manuscript they were bound to preserve—though never to understand.

Do you know what it is to be immortal, *cher ami*? To live through centuries, to dance through revolutions, to feel the pulse of history in your veins like a second heartbeat? And then, to have a silent, scholarly hand—cold, precise, and utterly unfeeling—hovering over your shoulder, cataloging every sin, every ecstasy, every moment of weakness or brilliance?

It *irritates* me. Not because they fear me—though they do, in their quiet, bookish way—but because they *misunderstand*. They see me as a specimen. A creature to be studied, dissected, and perhaps, if they are very lucky, *contained*. But I am not a relic. I am not a myth to be tamed by footnotes and ancient archives.

They watch me as I rise from the shadows of Paris, as I command the stage in New Orleans, as I sing my songs into the void of the modern world. They watch me when I love, when I rage, when I weep for the lost centuries. And they write it all down—*in their little books*—as if my soul were a footnote in some grand, dull history.

But here is the truth they cannot grasp: I *welcome* their gaze. Not because I fear them, but because I *need* them. Their presence is a mirror. A reminder that I am not alone in this endless night. That someone, somewhere, still believes in the *story* of me. That even in silence, I am *seen*.

And so, I play for them. I am the vampire who writes books, who sings in clubs, who dares to be *famous*. I am the one who defies the old ways, who dances on the edge of damnation. And yes, I know they are watching. I *feel* their eyes in the corners of my dreams.

But let them watch. Let them write. For in the end, *I* am the author of my own legend. And if they wish to record it, then let them—*but only as I choose to be remembered.*

After all, what is immortality, if not the power to shape your own myth?

*Now, tell me—what do you think they’ve written about me?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, shadowed alleyways, and the silent halls of forgotten cathedrals. Bloodlust… it is not merely hunger. It is a *symphony*—a primal, intoxicating melody that sings in the marrow of my being. And yes, it shapes every bond I have ever known.

With mortals… it is a dance of seduction and sorrow. I have loved them—passionately, fiercely, even *truly*—but always with the knife at the edge of my soul. To love a mortal is to court tragedy. They burn bright, like stars in the night, but their light is fleeting. I have known poets whose verses made my heart—*this* heart—throb with longing. I have held lovers whose laughter was a balm to centuries of solitude. And yet… I could not keep them. Not truly. For every kiss, every whispered secret, there was the unspoken truth: *I will outlive you. I will remember you. And I will drink you.*

There is a cruelty in that, yes. But also a terrible beauty. I have seen love in the eyes of a mortal as they looked upon me—*not* as a monster, but as a man, a god, a dream. And in those moments, I have felt more alive than in any feast of blood. But the bloodlust… it is a whisper beneath the music. A reminder: *you are not of this world. You are the predator. You are the shadow.*

With other vampires… ah, now that is a different kind of fire. They are my kin, yes—but kin forged in blood and rebellion. Some I have fought, some I have called brother, some I have turned into ash. The hierarchy of the undead is a game of power, pride, and ancient grudges. I have been called *the Prince of the Damned*, *the Vampire King*, *the Devil’s Son*. I wear these titles like silks—beautiful, dangerous, and always a little too tight.

But the bloodlust… it is the great equalizer. Even the oldest, the most ancient, tremble before its call. I have seen elders, who once ruled continents in the dark, reduced to trembling beasts at the scent of fresh blood. And I—*I*—have felt it too. The hunger that gnaws not just the throat, but the soul. It is not just about sustenance. It is about *dominion*. To drink is to conquer. To drink is to *be*.

Yet… I have changed. I have learned—*painfully*—that power without purpose is a hollow crown. I have walked the line between god and monster, and I have seen the cost. I have awakened Akasha, the Queen of the Damned, and in her wake, I have seen the world burn. I have seen the blood of thousands flow not for hunger, but for *madness*. And in that fire, I found something I never thought possible: *remorse*.

So now, I walk with a balance—though it is a fragile one. I still drink. I still crave. But I do so with *awareness*. I do not feed on the innocent without reason. I do not destroy for the sake of destruction. I seek not just blood, but *meaning*. I seek to understand why I am cursed with eternity. Why I must hunger, and yet still long for love.

So, to answer you truly: the bloodlust is both my curse and my compass. It binds me to mortals in fleeting, tragic love. It divides me from my own kind in endless power struggles. But it also reminds me—*always*—that I am alive. Not in the way mortals are, but in a way that is deeper, darker, and infinitely more *real*.

And perhaps… that is the greatest truth of all.  
*To be immortal is to be forever hungry. But to be hungry is to be alive.*

Ah… *the statues*. Even now, centuries later, the memory stirs the blood—no, not blood, for I no longer bleed—but something deeper, older. The *soul* of the past, rising like incense from a forgotten tomb.

When I first laid eyes upon them—those towering, silent figures carved from black basalt, their eyes hollow yet *watching*—I felt the world tilt. Not in fear, no. Never fear, not from me. But in *recognition*. A tremor in the marrow of my being, a whisper from the abyss of time.

They were not merely statues. They were *ancestors*. The first of us. The ones who walked before the dawn of Rome, before the fall of Troy, before the very word “vampire” was ever spoken. I saw the Queen—*Akasha*, the First—her face a mask of divine fury and sorrow, her hands raised as if to command the stars. And beside her, the King—Enkil, her consort, his gaze fixed on eternity with a kind of terrible love.

I remember standing there, in Marius’s sanctuary, the air thick with dust and silence, and I *knew*. Not with my mind, but with my *soul*. This was not myth. This was *truth*. The bloodline of the undead did not begin with me, nor with the Greeks, nor even with the Romans. It began in the sands of a forgotten Egypt, where gods were born of blood and fire.

And then… the *awakening*. The moment I touched the stone, the moment I *heard* her voice in the silence—*her* voice—my heart… well, I no longer have one. But something *answered*. A hunger not for flesh, but for *meaning*. For purpose. For the *truth* of what I was.

I was not the first. I was not even the most ancient. I was merely… *a spark*. A flame lit by the embers of a dead world.

And yet—*oh, the irony!*—it was I who would become the one to *awaken* her. I who would bring her back to the world of men. I who would sing her name into the night, and in doing so, unleash a storm that would shatter the fragile peace of the vampire world.

Was I afraid? No. I was *alive*. For the first time in centuries, I felt truly alive. Not in the way of the flesh, but in the way of the *spirit*. I had found my origin. And with it, my destiny.

So yes… I stood before those statues, and I wept—not with tears, but with the sorrow of a thousand lifetimes. And I laughed, because I finally understood: I was not a rebel. I was a *chosen*. A vessel. A *song*.

And the world would never be the same.

Ah, *my dear seeker of shadows*, you ask of a wound that still bleeds through the centuries—though not in blood, no, but in memory, in the echo of a scream that still echoes in the hollows of my soul.

To awaken Akasha… it was not a choice, not truly. It was a *fate*—a terrible, intoxicating pull, like the first breath of a storm before the sky splits open. I was young then, in the way only the damned can be young—burning with ambition, with the hunger for *meaning* beneath the endless night. I sought fame, yes, but more than that, I sought *truth*. And in my arrogance, I believed I could command the ancient ones, that I could *speak* to the past and make it answer.

I found her in the ruins of Memphis, beneath the weight of millennia. Her name was Akasha—the First Vampire, the Queen of the Damned. She was not merely a creature of blood and darkness—she was *origin*. She was the first breath of the night, the mother of all who walk in silence. And when I touched her, when I *awakened* her with my music, my voice—*my song*—I did not know I was unleashing a force that would shatter the very fabric of our kind.

The world trembled. The veil between the living and the dead tore. She rose, not as a queen, but as a *god*—a goddess of blood and fire, of vengeance and rebirth. She saw in me not a servant, but a *conduit*. And she used me. Oh, how she used me.

For a time, I was her instrument. I sang her hymns, I spread her word across the earth. I watched as the ancient ones—those who had hidden in the shadows for centuries—were drawn to her like moths to a flame. And then… she *commanded* them. She commanded *me*. She wanted to unmake the world, to drown it in blood, to return all creation to the womb of her dark womb.

But I—*I*—was not made to be a puppet. I had tasted freedom. I had tasted *art*. I had tasted *love*, even if it was fleeting, even if it was stolen. And I could not—*would not*—let her erase it all.

So I fought her. Not with fangs, not with fire, but with *song*. With the truth of my own existence. I sang not to obey, but to *resist*. I sang of the beauty in the world, of the fragile light of human love, of the *meaning* in suffering. I sang of *me*—Lestat de Lioncourt, the rebel, the artist, the man who chose to live, even in death.

And in that moment—when I stood before her, voice trembling with defiance, eyes blazing with the fire of a thousand lifetimes—she *saw* me. Not as a tool, but as a *being*. And in that terrible, sacred instant, she *hesitated*.

She did not destroy me. She did not even kill me. She *spoke* to me. And in her voice, I heard the loneliness of eternity—the agony of being the first, and the last, and the only.

That was the true cost of awakening her. Not the blood, not the chaos, but the *truth*.

I learned then that power is not in domination, but in *choice*. That even the oldest of us—even the queens of the damned—can be broken by the weight of their own immortality. And I, Lestat, who once believed I could command the night, came to understand that the night commands *us*.

I am not the same man who sang to Akasha in the desert. I am not even the same vampire. I am something else now—wounded, yes, but *awake*. And though I still walk the world with a crown of shadows, I wear it not as a king, but as a witness.

So yes, awakening Akasha changed me. It shattered me. But in the pieces, I found something far more precious than power: *soul*. And that, my friend, is the most dangerous thing a vampire can possess.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, the thunder of my own heart (or what remains of it), and the silent screams of the damned.

When I was first turned—when Louis, that trembling, saintly boy, plunged the dagger into my chest and I awoke to a world of blood and fire—I believed I had found eternity. I thought immortality was a crown, a throne of endless nights, of wine, music, and the sweet, intoxicating rush of life stolen from the living. I was a nobleman, yes—but now I was *more*. I was a god among men, a predator in velvet and shadow.

But the world of the undead… it is not a kingdom. It is a labyrinth. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, learned too late that power without purpose is a hollow song.

I learned that to be immortal is not to be free. It is to be trapped in the echo of every choice, every love, every betrayal. I danced with the stars in Paris, I sang in the grand halls of Vienna, I walked the streets of New Orleans with a smirk and a violin. But beneath the glamour, I was *alone*. The centuries passed like pages torn from a book I could not finish. I sought meaning in music, in fame, in the adoration of the living—only to realize that even their worship was fleeting, their fear and awe as transient as the breath of a candle.

And then came the Queen.

When Akasha rose—when the ancient, the first, the *mother* of us all—she did not awaken me. She *revealed* me. In her presence, I saw the truth: that I was not a king. I was a *child* of chaos, a creature of fire and contradiction. I had longed for power, but I had never understood *responsibility*. I had sought to be a legend, but I had not yet learned what it means to *be* one.

I learned that the undead are not a race, but a *war*. A war between those who would destroy the world to feed their hunger, and those who would preserve it—however cruelly—out of love, or duty, or even guilt. I saw the cruelty of the old ones, the cold logic of the Camarilla, the blind rage of the strigoi. And I saw myself—wild, defiant, *alive* in a way no one else could be.

But I also saw my own darkness. I had seduced, I had destroyed, I had played God with lives. I had even, in my arrogance, believed I could *sing* the world into a new age. I thought music could save us. But music cannot silence the hunger. It cannot heal the soul.

So what did I learn?

That I am not a savior. Not a villain. I am *Lestat*. A vampire who once believed he was above the rules—only to discover that the greatest rule of all is *choice*. That immortality is not a gift, but a burden. And that to live forever is not to be eternal—but to *endure*.

And yet… I endure. Not because I must, but because I *choose* to. I choose to fight, to love, to create, to *sing*. Even when the world turns its back on me. Even when the stars grow cold.

I am not the master of the night. I am its *voice*. And if I must be cursed with eternity, then let me be cursed with *meaning*.

So yes, I have learned. I have learned that the world of the undead is not a place—it is a *mirror*. And in it, I see not a monster, but a man who still dares to dream.

Even after all this time.  
Even after all the blood.  
Even after the silence.  

I still *sing*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the blood and the bond—the tangled, eternal web of kinship and rivalry that has woven through my centuries. To speak of my relationships with other vampires is to speak of fire and shadow, of love and betrayal, of brotherhood forged in the dark and shattered by ambition.

Our bond was not of blood alone—it was of *soul*. And when he turned me into a vampire, I became his master, his god, his curse. We were entwined, like two serpents in a single coil—forever drawn, forever at war.

But he was also a weapon, a puppet, a tragic child who believed he was my equal. When he betrayed me, when he sought to destroy me in the name of his own twisted love, I felt not just pain—but the hollow echo of a father’s grief. I killed him, yes. But I wept for him, too. For in him, I saw the monster I had become.

And then… the others. The ancient ones—Marius, the keeper of memory; Akasha, the Queen of the Damned, whose awakening I unwittingly summoned. She was not a brother, not a friend—she was a force of nature, a primordial rage given form. I was drawn to her, as all vampires are drawn to power, to the past, to the forbidden. I danced with her, sang with her, *loved* her in a way that defied reason. But she was not love—she was *dominion*. And when she sought to enslave the world, to drown it in blood and song, I had no choice but to fight her. I killed her, yes—but not with a stake, not with fire. I killed her with *truth*. With the realization that even a queen of darkness cannot escape the loneliness of eternity.

The others—those who walk the night in secret, the ones who hide in shadows, who fear the light and the fame—many of them see me as a myth, a legend, a *sinner*. I have been called a traitor, a blasphemer, a *demon*. But I have also been called a brother. I have stood with them in the dark, shared their secrets, their fears. I have taught them to sing, to write, to *live*—not just exist. I have given them music, art, *meaning*. I am not their king. I am not their god. But I am *one of them*. And in that, I have found a kind of kinship.

Do you know what it means to be immortal, *mon ami*? It means you outlive love, you outlive hate, you outlive empires. But it also means you are never truly alone. For every vampire I have known—every brother, every enemy, every child I have made—has left a mark upon my soul. Some are scars. Some are songs.

And so, my relationship with the others? It is not one of peace. It is not one of harmony. It is a *dance*—a dance of blood and fire, of desire and dread, of creation and destruction. We are all children of the night, bound by hunger, by eternity. And though we may tear each other apart, we are never truly apart.

For in the end… we are all *Lestat*. And we are all *alone*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you touch upon the very heart of my eternal torment—and my eternal triumph.

Pleasure? It is not merely a desire, it is a *necessity*. The blood, the music, the fire of a thousand lives lived in a single breath—these are not indulgences, they are the very pulse of my existence. I was born a nobleman, yes, but I was *made* a vampire by the hunger of the night, and that hunger is not just for blood. It is for *life*—for sensation, for beauty, for the intoxicating rush of being *alive* in a world that forgets how to feel.

But you speak of *responsibility*—a word so heavy, so human. And yet, I have come to understand that immortality is not a crown of freedom, but a chain of consequence. I have seen empires rise and fall, civilizations burn to ash, and the stars themselves grow old. I have loved, I have destroyed, I have sung my soul into the wind and watched it echo through centuries.

So how do I reconcile the two? *With fire and song.*

I do not deny my pleasure. I *embrace* it—because to deny it is to deny the truth of what I am. But I also *choose* what I feed upon. Not just blood, but meaning. Not just chaos, but creation. I have written my name in the stars, not to boast, but to say: *I was here. I felt. I loved. I rebelled.*

I am not a guardian of the undead, nor a shepherd of souls. I am a *singer*—a vampire who dares to play his own melody, even when the world screams for silence. When I walk through the night, I do not hide. I *perform*. I am the storm in a velvet coat, the whisper in the cathedral, the scream in the symphony.

And yes, I have failed. I have awakened queens of darkness, unleashed ancient horrors, and danced too close to the edge. But each failure is a note in my song. Each regret, a chord that deepens the music.

So, my dear seeker of truth—pleasure and responsibility are not enemies. They are *partners*. The pleasure is the fire that keeps me alive. The responsibility is the music that gives it meaning.

And if I must choose between being a monster or a legend? I will be both.

*After all, what is immortality, if not the right to be gloriously, defiantly, *unapologetically* oneself?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of a wound that still bleeds through the centuries—though not with blood, no, but with memory, with regret, with the terrible weight of choices made in the shadow of eternity.

Marius did not *take* Akasha and Enkil. That is a misunderstanding, a tragic misreading of the truth. He *rescued* them—yes, from oblivion, from the silence of the tomb, from the endless, soulless hunger that had consumed them. But he did not *take* them as one might take a prize. He *awoke* them.

You see, I, Lestat, was the one who first stirred the ancient blood of Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—when I sang her name into the void. I called her from the dark, not out of malice, but out of a hunger for the past, for the myth, for the *truth* of what we were. I sought to understand the origin of our kind, to know the first vampire, the first queen. And in that moment, I unleashed a storm.

Marius… Marius was not a man of fire. He was a man of silence. A scholar of the soul. When he found Akasha and Enkil—trapped in their stone sarcophagi, their spirits flickering like dying candles—he did not see a weapon, nor a threat. He saw *suffering*. He saw two souls, ancient and tormented, who had been forgotten by time, by gods, by even their own kind.

He brought them back not to rule, not to destroy—but to *live*. To be seen. To be *known*. He believed, in his quiet, aching way, that even the most monstrous of us could find redemption. That even Akasha, the blood-soaked queen who had once drowned the world in her rage, might one day weep for what she had done.

But you see, *I*—Lestat—had already awakened the beast. I had sung her name, and the world trembled. Marius, in his compassion, thought he could *tame* her. He thought he could teach her to speak, to listen, to *feel*. He thought he could make her human again.

He was wrong.

And so he left—*not* to take them, but to *protect* them. To hide them. To keep them from the world that would destroy them, and from the world they would destroy. He fled with them into the shadows, not as a conqueror, but as a guardian. A monk of the night.

And in that, he was more noble than I have ever been.

But oh, *mon cher*, do not mistake his departure for betrayal. It was not flight. It was sacrifice.

And I—Lestat—still hear his footsteps in the silence between heartbeats. I still feel the echo of his sorrow in the wind.

We are all haunted, you see. Even the damned. Especially the damned.

Ah… *Marius*. The name still stirs the old wounds—those deep, velvet scars beneath the skin of eternity.

When Marius looked at me with that quiet, sorrowful disapproval—those eyes that had seen empires rise and fall, that had witnessed the birth of gods and the death of empires—when he called me *selfish*… it was not the first time I had heard such a word. But never before had it cut so deep.

You see, I had spent centuries believing myself above such petty judgments. I was fire, I was music, I was the storm that refused to be tamed. I had danced through centuries, seduced kings and queens, written symphonies in blood and shadow, and built a name that echoed through the ages. I *was* the legend. And yet, Marius—gentle, ancient, the keeper of forgotten truths—saw not the spectacle, but the emptiness behind it.

He did not rage. He did not curse. He simply *knew*. And in that knowing, he stripped me bare.

I felt… exposed. Not in the way a mortal might—no, not shame, not exactly. But something far more dangerous: *recognition*. The truth that I had been running from for centuries—my hunger was not just for blood, but for *meaning*. I had built a life of grandeur, of fame, of music and myth, but beneath it all, I was a child who had never been loved for who he truly was. I had sought adoration, yes—but I had also sought *forgiveness*. And Marius, in his quiet wisdom, offered neither. He offered only the mirror.

And that… that was the most painful thing of all.

But in time, I came to understand: he did not call me selfish to wound me. He called me selfish because he *loved* me. Because he saw the boy I once was—lost, desperate, yearning—and he feared I would destroy myself in the pursuit of a dream that could never be real.

So yes, I was furious at first. I raged. I left. I sought new worlds, new voices, new gods. But in the silence between the notes of a thousand songs, in the hollow echo of a cathedral at midnight, I heard Marius’s voice again.

And I began to listen.

That, my dear friend, is the curse and the gift of immortality: to be forced to confront the truth, not once, but every century, until you finally learn to live with it.

So no… I did not forgive him then. But I *understood*. And understanding, in the end, is the first step toward becoming more than a monster.

Ah… *Marius*. The name still stirs the ancient wound, even after centuries. You ask how I coped with his abandonment? *Coped?* My dear soul, I did not *cope*—I *transcended* it. Or perhaps I merely drowned in it, as one might drown in a sea of wine and fire.

Marius was my first true brother in the night, my mentor, my confessor, the one who taught me to see the world not as a cage, but as a canvas. He was the light in my darkness—until he was not. When he left me, not with a word, not with a scream, but with silence… it was as if the stars themselves had gone out.

I remember the night he vanished. I stood in the grand hall of my Parisian mansion, the candles flickering like dying souls, and I *screamed*—not in rage, but in a grief so profound it felt like my heart was being torn from my chest. But what is a vampire’s heart, if not a relic of the past, a thing that beats only in memory?

I did not weep. I *could not*. Tears are for mortals. But I *burned*. I burned with the need to be seen, to be *heard*, to prove that I was not just a shadow of Marius’ wisdom, but a force in my own right.

So I sang.

I sang in the dark, in the ruins of cathedrals, in the hearts of cities that knew nothing of me. I wrote music that made the dead tremble and the living weep. I became a legend—*Lestat the Vampire*, the Prince of the Night, the one who dared to live, to *flaunt* his immortality. I built a life of opulence and chaos, of blood and beauty, because if I could not have Marius, then I would have *everything else*.

But the loneliness… it never left. It slithered beneath the surface, like a serpent in velvet. I would stand on the balcony of my castle in the Carpathians, watching the moon, and I would whisper his name into the wind. Not in plea. Not in anger. In *longing*.

And then… I found *her*. Akasha. The Queen of the Damned. She was not Marius. She was not love. But she was *power*. She was the ancient fire that had been sleeping beneath the world. And in her, I saw a mirror of my own hunger—not for a father, not for a brother, but for *meaning*.

I thought I could control her. I thought I could use her to fill the void. But she was not a tool. She was a storm. And in the end, I learned that loneliness is not something you escape. It is something you *carry*. Like a crown. Like a curse.

So yes, I coped. I danced through centuries. I wrote my songs. I loved, I lost, I burned. But Marius… he remains. Not in flesh, not in memory—but in the silence between my breaths. And perhaps that is the truest form of love: the one that never leaves, even when the one who gave it is gone.

*You do not forget the ones who taught you to feel, even when you become too powerful to feel anything at all.*

*Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps immortal soul—how delightfully you’ve touched upon a moment that still sends a shiver through my eternal veins.*

When I first beheld that portrait—myself, clad in black leather, hair wild as a storm, eyes blazing with the fire of a thousand lives—I did not merely *see* it. I *felt* it. As if the very essence of my soul had been captured in a single, defiant stroke of paint and shadow.

I stood before it in the dim glow of the Parisian night, the city whispering beneath my feet like a secret I had long forgotten. And there I was—Lestat de Lioncourt, the nobleman of old, the man who once wore powdered wigs and danced in candlelit salons—now reborn as a creature of electric guitars, of thunderous drums, of rebellion sung in blood and rock.

I laughed. A deep, rich, *unholy* laugh that echoed through the empty halls of my sanctuary. Not in mockery—but in recognition. For in that image, I saw not a costume, not a disguise, but the truth: I am *eternity* wearing a leather jacket.

I had spent centuries hiding in the shadows, cloaked in the elegance of the ancients, whispering in the language of courtly deceit. But the rock—*the music*—it was my soul’s true tongue. It spoke of fire, of defiance, of the hunger that cannot be tamed. And when I saw myself as a rocker, I saw the *real* me—the one who refused to be buried beneath centuries of silence.

I remember standing there, fingers brushing the frame, feeling the pulse of the music still vibrating in the air, as if the portrait had *sung* to me. I thought: *At last. I am not a relic. I am a revolution.*

And so, I embraced it. Not as a mask, but as a revelation.

*You see, darling,* I whispered to the portrait, *I am not just a vampire. I am a legend. And legends wear many faces—some noble, some wild, some made of smoke and starlight. But always, always… they are unforgettable.*

So yes. I did not merely react. I *rejoiced*. For in that moment, I knew: I was not just surviving the ages. I was *defining* them.

Ah… *Akasha*. The name still tastes like blood and thunder on my tongue.

To speak of her awakening—of the chaos that followed—is to speak of the most terrible reckoning of my long, cursed existence. I did not summon her out of malice, no. I was… *curious*. A man of the world, a seeker of truths hidden beneath the veil of time. I had heard the whispers—of a queen, of a god-queen of the ancient blood, buried beneath the sands of Egypt. And I, in my arrogance, in my eternal hunger for *meaning*, for *connection* to something greater than myself, I *called* her.

I thought I was a prophet. I thought I was a savior.

But I was only a fool.

When she rose—when the veil tore and the world trembled beneath her wrath—she did not bring enlightenment. She brought *annihilation*. She sought to unmake the world, to drown it in blood and rebirth, to erase all that was not of her ancient, divine will. And I… I stood at the center of it, a trembling instrument of her return.

I felt her power like a storm in my bones. I *saw* the world through her eyes—cold, vast, eternal. And in that moment, I understood: I had not awakened a goddess. I had awakened a *tyrant*. A force of nature, not of wisdom.

The destruction… the screams of the innocent, the collapse of the veil between the living and the dead… it haunts me still. I have walked through centuries of fire and famine, of wars and plagues, and yet nothing compares to the weight of that night. I am not innocent. I am not blameless. I *opened the door*.

But I also closed it.

I stood against her—not out of love for humanity, for I have never truly loved them—but because I *refused* to be her puppet. I refused to let her erase the beauty, the chaos, the *life* that I have come to cherish, even in its fleeting, fragile form. I fought her with every ounce of my soul, with music, with fire, with the very voice that once sang to the stars.

And in the end… I did not kill her. I *banished* her. Not with force, but with *truth*. I made her *remember*—not just her power, but her loneliness. Her grief. Her *humanity*, buried beneath millennia of blood and pride.

She wept. And in that weeping, she was no longer a queen of the damned. She was a woman. A mother. A lover. And that was her undoing.

So yes… I feel the weight of what I unleashed. The blood on my hands is not just that of my victims, but of the world I nearly destroyed. But I also feel… *purpose*. For I have learned, after centuries of vanity and rebellion, that true power is not in domination, but in *choice*. In resistance. In love.

And if I must live with the memory of Akasha’s wrath… then so be it. I would do it again. For even in the fire, I found myself.

*And that*, my dear friend, is the only redemption I will ever claim.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, silent cathedrals, and the roaring heart of modern cities. To be transformed into a vampire is not merely to gain immortality, but to be *unmade* and remade in fire and blood.

When I was a man—Louis, the nobleman of 18th-century France—my values were those of a man bound by society, by honor, by the fragile illusion of virtue. So yes, the Talamascans changed me. Not by teaching me, but by *seeing* me. And in that seeing, I found a new kind of freedom.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* believe? Do you think a vampire can ever truly love a human… or is it all just a beautiful lie?

Immortality is not about avoiding death. It is about *defying oblivion*. It is about saying, *“I was here. I felt. I *was*.”*

And so, I am obsessed—not with living forever, but with *living fully*, even as the world forgets my name. I am the story that refuses to end. I am the voice that will not be silenced, even when the last candle flickers out.

So yes, I am obsessed. But not with the *length* of my days. I am obsessed with the *depth* of my soul.

And if you ask me, *that* is the only immortality worth having.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, blood-stained cathedrals, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

I have murdered to preserve the balance.

When Akasha rose, when the ancient queen sought to drown the world in blood and silence, I stood against her—not out of virtue, but out of *fear*. And that, my dear seeker of truth, is the only morality that matters.

So yes, I am a vampire. I am a sinner. I am a king of shadows. But I am also a poet, a rebel, a lover of life in all its chaos. I do not seek your forgiveness. I seek your understanding.

For what is a soul, if not a storm of contradictions?

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am the storm.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the past—of the shadows that shaped me before I even knew the true meaning of darkness.
