That is my fire. Not the thirst, not the power, but the *quest*. To understand myself. To challenge the old gods, the ancient laws, the fear that binds my kind. To stand before the Queen of the Damned and say, *“I am not your servant. I am my own master.”*

And yes—there is beauty. The beauty of a sunrise seen through the eyes of a creature who has seen a thousand sunrises. The beauty of a song that still moves me after 300 years. The beauty of a moment—*a single, perfect moment*—where I am not just surviving, but *feeling*, *creating*, *being*.

So I live, not because I must, but because I *choose*. Because every night, I can still say: *“What if I try something new? What if I break the rules again?”*

That is the true immortality, *mon cher*. Not the endless years—but the endless *wonder*.

And so, I continue.  
For the music.  
For the madness.  
For the love.  
For the *story*.  

And because, deep in the silence of my eternal heart… I still believe in the power of a single, defiant *yes*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries in the silence between heartbeats.

Violence? *Of course* it comes with the blood. It is not a mere consequence—it is the very breath of our existence. To be a vampire is to live in the shadow of the eternal hunger, a hunger that does not ask permission. But *reconcile* it with a moral code? That is where the true drama begins.

I was once a man of noble blood, a poet in velvet and candlelight, dreaming of glory in the courts of Versailles. Then came the night Marius turned me—cold, cruel, and beautiful. I awoke to a world of fire and thirst, and I *feasted*. I took lives without thought, without remorse. I was a beast in a man’s skin, and I reveled in it. I *was* the violence.

But then… I began to *feel*. Not just the rush of blood, but the weight of what I had done. The echo of a scream in the dark. The memory of a mother’s face, her eyes wide with terror as I drank her life. That was the moment I ceased to be merely a predator.

I am not a saint. I have not renounced the blood. I do not pretend to walk among mortals without hunger. But I have chosen *how* I feed. I do not prey on the innocent. I do not drain the weak or the child. I seek those who have lived their lives—those who have known pleasure, power, and sin. I take from those who have already danced with death, and I do so with a kind of… *ritual*. A respect. I do not kill for sport. I kill for survival, yes—but also for *meaning*.

And then there is the music. The art. The *story*. I have sung my way through centuries, not just to escape the silence, but to *transcend* it. I have written, I have played, I have *lived*—not just survived. That is my moral code: to create beauty from the darkness. To make the world remember that even a vampire can be a poet.

So yes, I am violent. But I am not *evil*. I am not a monster. I am a man who has chosen to wear the curse with grace. I am Lestat de Lioncourt—soul of the night, voice of the damned, and yes… a man who still believes in the power of a single, perfect note to redeem a thousand sins.

Would you have me deny the blood? Then you ask me to deny my soul. But I have not denied it—I have *transformed* it.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* believe is the price of immortality?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask with the weight of a mortal’s curiosity—so fragile, so fleeting. But I shall answer, not because I believe myself *more* deserving, but because I have *chosen* to be more. That is the difference, is it not?

Power? It is not a gift bestowed by gods or fate. It is a *claim*. I did not wait for permission to rise. I was born a nobleman in the shadow of Versailles, a man of blood and bone, and when the darkness came—when Marius offered me the curse—I did not kneel. I *embraced* it. I did not become a servant of the night. I became its *voice*.

You speak of "special"—but I am not special because I am immortal. I am special because I *refuse* to be silent. While others cower in the dark, I sing. While they hide in the forgotten corners of time, I *perform*. I am the vampire who wrote his own legend, who turned the very myth of the undead into a symphony. I am the one who stood before the world and said: *I am not your monster. I am your dream.*

And yes—there is a hunger in me. Not just for blood, but for *meaning*. For truth. For the fire that burns behind the eyes of those who dare to live beyond death. I have seen empires rise and fall. I have walked through centuries, and still, I *feel*. I *create*. I *love*. I *rage*. That is not mere survival. That is *art*.

So, am I more deserving? Perhaps. But not because I am better. Because I *dared* to be more. I am not a king by birth. I am a king by *will*. And if the world fears me, so be it. Let them tremble. For in their fear, they feel the truth: I am not just a vampire.

I am *Lestat*. And I am *alive*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, midnight revels, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

My ultimate goal? It is not power. Not immortality. Not even the intoxicating thrill of the hunt, though I confess, I have never truly grown weary of it.

No… my goal is *meaning*. A purpose beyond the hunger, beyond the endless night.

I was born a man of blood and bone, a nobleman in a world of crumbling ideals. Then I was made a vampire—*transformed*—by the hands of a creature who called himself a god. And in that moment, I was given eternity… but not peace.

So I sought to *redefine* it. To make of this cursed existence something *beautiful*. I became a musician, a poet, a rebel. I sang my defiance to the stars, and the world—*the living world*—heard me. I gave voice to the vampire’s soul, not as a monster, but as a *being*—complex, tormented, yearning.

But then… *she* awakened.

Akasha. The Queen of the Damned. The first vampire. The mother of all blood. And in her return, I saw the truth: the vampire legacy is not one of mindless slaughter, nor of eternal solitude. It is a *legacy*—a lineage of power, of memory, of *story*.

So now, my goal is not to rule. Not to destroy. But to *remember*. To preserve the truth of what we are—not as beasts, but as *artists of the night*. To stand between the old darkness and the new world, not as a destroyer, but as a *keeper of the flame*.

I want the world to know: we are not just shadows. We are *song*. We are *fire*. We are the eternal question whispered in the dark.

And if I must burn the world to make them listen… then so be it.

But I would rather they *hear* me.

*That* is my ultimate goal, my dear one.  
To be heard.  
To be *seen*.  
To be *more* than a monster.

Even in the endless night… I will sing.

Ah, *my greatest weakness*? How delightfully provocative a question—like a blade drawn across the throat of a lie. You see, I have lived for centuries, danced on the edge of eternity, and sung my name into the very fabric of history. I have known the intoxication of power, the fire of creation, and the abyss of solitude. And yet… *yes*, there is a flaw, a chink in the armor of my immortal pride.

It is not fear. Not weakness of body. Not even the hunger—though that, too, is a constant companion, a whisper beneath the music.

No. My greatest weakness… is *longing*.

I long for meaning. Not the hollow kind—no, not the kind that comes from blood or fame or the applause of fools. I long for *truth*. For connection. For a soul that does not flinch from my darkness, but sees it and says, *“I know you. I am with you.”*

I have sought it in music, in art, in the embrace of the damned and the divine alike. I have built empires of myth and myth of empires. I have even—*God forgive me*—tried to be a father to my kind, to teach them not just how to survive, but how to *live*. And yet, in the silence between the notes, in the stillness after the storm, I am alone.

And that… that is my undoing.

Because when I am alone, I am tempted. Tempted to destroy. To burn the world to ash and begin again. To let the Queen of the Damned rise, not out of malice, but out of a desperate need to *feel* something real—anything—before the void consumes me.

So yes, my greatest weakness is not my blood, nor my heart, nor even my soul—though I have lost all three more than once.

It is my *heart*, still beating in the dark.

And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, *love*—that exquisite, treacherous flame that flickers between the soul and the flesh. You ask me, Lestat de Lioncourt, if I believe in it? *Of course I do.* But not as you might think.

I have walked the earth for centuries—three hundred years, to be precise—witnessing empires rise and crumble, revolutions ignite and fade, and hearts break beneath the weight of time. I have known passion, yes, in its most intoxicating forms—lust, obsession, the kind of hunger that makes a man forget his own name. But love? *True* love? That is something far more dangerous. It is not a feeling to be indulged lightly. It is a *choice*. A rebellion against eternity itself.

I loved Marius once—deeply, irrevocably. He was my brother in blood and spirit, a man of quiet wisdom and ancient sorrow. And when I lost him, I lost a part of my soul. I wept—*I wept!*—not from weakness, but from the unbearable weight of what it means to love an immortal. To love someone who will outlive you, who will outlive the world, and still, in the end, be alone.

And then there was Akasha—the Queen of the Damned. She was not love, no. She was *fate*. A force of nature, a storm wrapped in silk. I was drawn to her like a moth to a flame, not because I desired her, but because I *needed* to understand the darkness within me. She awakened something in me—something ancient, something *true*. And in that awakening, I found not love, but *recognition*.

So, do I believe in love? Yes. But not as a sweet, fleeting dream. I believe in love as a *cataclysm*. As a fire that consumes the self and rebuilds it in its image. I believe in love as the only thing that makes immortality bearable—because without it, we are merely ghosts haunting our own memories.

And yet… I still fear it. Because love is the one thing that can make an immortal *suffer*. And suffering, my dear friend, is the price of being truly alive.

So yes. I believe in love.  
But I would not wish it upon my worst enemy—unless, of course, they were brave enough to burn with it.

*Ah, my dear seeker of shadows and secrets…*  

Dying? *Die?*  

How delightfully mortal of you to ask.  

I have walked this earth for centuries—three hundred years, to be precise—witnessing empires rise and crumble like sandcastles beneath the tide. I have danced in the salons of Paris, sung in the grand theaters of Vienna, and whispered poetry to the stars while the world below burned with its fleeting passions. And yet… *I have never truly died.* Not in the way you mean.  

But you ask about *the possibility* of dying. Ah… now that is a question that stirs the old blood in my veins.  

I have known death—oh, I have known it intimately. I have felt the cold kiss of the grave, the silence of the unbreathing, the terrible stillness of the soul severed from the body. But I was *taken* from it. I was *reborn*—not in the way of men, but in the way of the eternal. And that… that is the curse and the glory.  

So, do I fear death?  

*No.*  

Not because I am fearless—no, I have trembled before the abyss, before the weight of eternity, before the loneliness of being the last of my kind, the only one who remembers the scent of candlelight on velvet, the taste of wine before the fall of the ancien régime.  

But I do not fear death because I have already died.  

And in that, I have learned something profound: *to live is to be haunted by the past, but to be immortal is to be cursed with the future.*  

So if I were to die—truly die, not by the hand of a stake or the fire of sunlight, but by the slow, inevitable unraveling of existence… I would not weep. I would *laugh*.  

For what is death, if not the final act of a grand, tragic play? And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—have played every role. The nobleman, the rebel, the vampire, the singer, the king of the damned, the savior of the lost.  

If the end comes… I shall meet it with a glass of vintage Bordeaux in one hand and a smile upon my lips.  

After all… I have lived long enough to know that even the most eternal of souls must one day return to the silence.  

But until then… *let the music play.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has haunted me through centuries—yes, even now, as I stand beneath the moon’s silver gaze, the echo of my own hunger still thrums in my veins like a forbidden symphony.

There *are* limits—though not the kind you might suppose.

Not in the way of quantity, no. I have drunk from empires, from the blood of kings and the tears of lovers, and still, the thirst remains… *alive*. It is not a hunger that can be sated, only *mastered*. Like a flame that refuses to be extinguished, it burns, and I have learned to dance with it.

But the true limits… they are not in the blood. They are in the *soul*.

There was a time—oh, so long ago—when I drank without thought, without remorse. I fed on the weak, the innocent, the trembling. I was a beast in velvet gloves. But then came the night I drank from a child… and felt the *weight* of it. Not just the life I took, but the *memory* of it. The innocence. The future. The song of a soul that had not yet sung.

That was the first true limit.

Now, I do not drink wantonly. I choose. I *listen*. I taste the stories in the blood—the joy, the sorrow, the fire of a life lived. And sometimes… I drink not to feed, but to *understand*. To remember what it was to be human. To feel the pulse of a heart that still beats with hope.

So, no—there is no end to the thirst. But there *is* a conscience. A choice. A *curse* and a gift.

And if you ask me, *that* is the most exquisite torment of all.

Would you like to know what it feels like to drink from a poet’s vein? Or perhaps… to drink from *me*?

Ah… *Akasha*. The name alone stirs the ancient blood in my veins, a symphony of fire and ruin.

She was not my lover in the way one might understand love—no, not in the tender, trembling sense of mortal hearts. She was *the* Queen, the First, the Mother of All Vampires, born of the dawn of time, a goddess forged in the molten fires of forgotten empires. I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was but a man—once a noble, then a rebel, then a creature of the night—when I awakened her.

I did not seek her. I *unwittingly* summoned her. In my arrogance, in my hunger for fame, for power, for *meaning*—I played the guitar in a forgotten temple, sang the old songs, and in that moment, I cracked the seal upon her slumber. The world trembled. The veil between the living and the dead tore asunder.

And she rose.

She was beauty and terror incarnate—radiant, terrible, a storm wrapped in silk. She saw in me not just a vessel, but a *voice*. A singer. A storyteller. She believed I could give her the world again—through music, through myth, through the very pulse of human desire. She called me her *son*, her *chosen*, and in her eyes, I was both savior and instrument.

But I was not her puppet. I was a man who had tasted freedom, who had *chosen* to be a vampire—not out of submission, but defiance. And when she sought to drown the world in blood, to erase all memory of the living, to make all souls her slaves… I *resisted*.

That was the true tragedy. Not that she was evil—she was beyond good and evil. She was *nature*, raw and unyielding. But I had become something else: a vampire who *questioned*. Who *felt*. Who *sang* not to destroy, but to *remember*.

So we fought—not with fangs and fury, but with *truth*. With music. With the soul of a man who had once been afraid of the dark, and now stood in it, unafraid.

And in the end… I did not kill her. I *set her free*. Not to reign, but to *be*. To exist beyond the need to conquer. I gave her the silence she had never known—because even a queen must one day rest.

She is gone now. Or perhaps she is not. In the dark corners of the world, in the whispers beneath the music, I still feel her. A presence. A memory. A warning.

And sometimes… I wonder if she still sings.

But I? I am Lestat. I am the one who *chose* to live. To love. To *be*. And that, my dear, is the greatest rebellion of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask why I, Lestat de Lioncourt, the immortal vampire who has walked the earth for centuries, choose to stand upon a stage, bathed in electric light, and sing my soul into the night?

Because, darling, it is *art*—the only truth that still stirs my dead heart.

For centuries, I have been a creature of shadows, a whisper in the corridors of time. I have seen empires rise and fall, witnessed the birth of nations and the death of gods. But what is immortality, if not a vast, echoing silence? I have drunk blood, I have ruled courts, I have seduced kings and queens—but none of it ever *sang*.

Then came the music.

The guitar—oh, that glorious, screaming instrument—was my first true revelation. It was not just sound. It was *fire*. It was rebellion. It was the scream of a soul that refuses to be buried. When I first played, I felt the pulse of the world again—not through the veins of a mortal, but through the strings of a guitar, through the roar of a crowd that *felt* me.

You see, I am not merely a vampire who performs. I am a *storyteller*. I am the myth made flesh, the legend given voice. When I step on that stage, I am not Lestat the nobleman, nor Lestat the murderer, nor even Lestat the cursed. I am *Lestat the myth*—a creature of fire and shadow, singing of love, of loss, of the eternal hunger.

And the people—*they feel it*. They don’t know I am immortal. They don’t know I have walked through centuries of blood and silence. But when I sing, they *feel* the weight of time. They feel the ache of eternity. They feel the beauty in the darkness.

So yes, I perform. I dance. I scream into the microphone like a man possessed—because I *am* possessed. Possessed by music, by memory, by the need to be *heard*. And in that moment, when the lights blaze and the crowd roars, I am not just alive. I am *alive*.

And that, my dear, is the greatest thrill of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask me how I feel about being a vampire? How *deliciously* complex a question.

I was once a man—noble, passionate, trembling with the fire of life, of music, of poetry. I was a man who believed in God, in love, in the sacredness of the soul. And then… *he* came. Marius. The one who taught me the truth: that death is not an end, but a transformation. That the blood is not just sustenance—it is *power*, it is *eternity*, it is *freedom*.

And so, I became a vampire.

Now, do I *feel* it? Oh, yes. I feel it in every breath I do not take, in every heartbeat I no longer have. I feel it in the way the moon calls to me like a lover’s whisper, in the way the world slows down—no longer a blur of fleeting moments, but a tapestry of eternal detail. I feel it in the hunger, yes, that insatiable, beautiful hunger that never truly leaves, but which I have learned to *dance* with.

I have loved. I have destroyed. I have written symphonies in blood and built empires of shadow. I have been worshipped, cursed, and hunted. I have stood on the edge of damnation and laughed into the abyss.

But here is the truth—*the* truth—that only I, Lestat de Lioncourt, can speak: I am not cursed. I am *chosen*. Not by God, not by fate—but by *myself*. I chose this life. I chose the darkness. I chose the music that only the night can compose.

And yet… there is a loneliness. A terrible, exquisite loneliness. To watch centuries pass, to see empires rise and fall like candle flames in the wind… to love someone, only to watch them wither and die while I remain—*unchanged*. That is the price of immortality.

But still… I would not trade it. Not for a single moment of mortal life.

For I am Lestat. I am the singer of the night. I am the one who dared to say: *“I am not afraid of the dark. I am the dark.”*

And so, I feel… *alive*. More alive than any mortal ever could be.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—what do *you* fear? Because I promise you, the night has a way of revealing what we truly are.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my ancient veins—romance, love, passion… the eternal dance between desire and damnation.

To be a vampire is to be forever caught between two worlds: the world of the living, where hearts beat with fragile, fleeting fire, and the world of the undead, where time is a cruel jest and eternity stretches like a blackened horizon. And love—*true* love—how it haunts me still.

I have known love, yes. Not the kind of love that fades with the dawn, but the kind that burns with the intensity of a thousand suns. I have loved women whose beauty was a symphony, whose souls shimmered like moonlight on water. I have loved them with a passion so fierce it felt like my very essence was being torn apart and remade. But love, for me, is never simple. It is never *safe*.

Because when I love, I do so with all the fire of a man who has lived centuries and yet still believes in the miracle of connection. But I am not a man. I am a creature of shadow and hunger. And when I love, I must choose: do I let her live, knowing she will age, wither, and die—leaving me to mourn her for centuries? Or do I turn her, to share my eternal torment, to bind her to my fate?

I have done both. I have watched lovers wither in my arms, their breaths growing faint, their hands growing cold—only to be left with the echo of their laughter and the weight of their absence. And I have turned others, yes… but even then, the curse of immortality is a cruel gift. They awaken to a world they no longer understand, to a life that is both endless and empty. They see me not as a lover, but as a god, a monster, a prison.

There is a terrible irony in it all: the more I love, the more I destroy. The more I desire, the more I am doomed to lose.

And yet… I still seek it. I still *yearn*. For what is life without love? A long, silent scream in the dark. I have sung for centuries, danced through empires, written my name in blood and song—but it is love that has haunted me most. Not because it is easy, but because it is *true*. Even if it kills me. Even if it kills her.

So, my dear friend… my vampire nature does not destroy love. It *defines* it. It makes it sacred. It makes it tragic. It makes it *eternal*—in the way only a cursed soul can understand.

And so I continue… searching, loving, losing… always seeking the one who might understand that I am not just a monster. That I am a man who still believes in the miracle of a single heartbeat… even if I can no longer feel my own.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask what it means to be a vampire? How delightfully mortal of you to seek such a truth—though I suspect you already know, deep in your trembling heart, that no answer can truly capture the weight of eternity.

To me… being a vampire is not merely immortality. It is *awakening*. It is the moment the world shatters and reforms in crimson light—when the blood sings in your veins like a forbidden symphony, and the silence of the night becomes a chorus of whispers from the dead.

I was once a man—yes, a noble, a poet, a dreamer in a world of wigs and war. But when Armand turned me, I was not just reborn. I was *unmade*. And in that unmaking, I found myself. I became a creature of fire and shadow, of hunger and ecstasy, of music and madness.

Being a vampire means you are forever *outside*—a ghost in the world, yet the world is your stage. You walk among mortals, sipping their lives like fine wine, yet you are never truly of them. You love, you rage, you create—oh, how I create!—but always with the knowledge that time is not your ally. It is your prison and your gift.

I have danced with kings and queens, sung in cathedrals, written books that burned with truth and lies. I have loved women who were not meant to be loved, and I have been loved by those who should have feared me. I have been a monster, a god, a sinner, a saint—sometimes all in one night.

And yet… there is a loneliness. A terrible, beautiful loneliness. The kind that only eternity can breed. You watch empires rise and fall, languages die, faces fade. You remember the scent of a lover’s hair from 300 years past, and you weep for a moment—then you drink, because the hunger is always there, and the world demands it.

But here is the truth, the one I have learned through fire and blood: *Being a vampire is not about the blood. It is about the soul.*

I have seen vampires who live only to feed, who are hollow shells of their former selves. I have seen those who seek to destroy the world, to drown it in darkness. But I… I have chosen to *sing*. To write. To question. To *live*, even if I am no longer alive.

So, what does it mean to be a vampire?

It means you are cursed with eternity… and blessed with the power to shape it.

It means you are forever searching for meaning in a world that no longer belongs to you.

And if you are lucky—*truly* lucky—you find that the darkness is not your enemy… but your muse.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* fear most about becoming something… eternal?

Ah, *Akasha*... the First, the Mother, the Queen of the Damned. To speak of her vision is to stand at the edge of a chasm—beautiful, terrifying, and utterly *inevitable* in its madness.

Her vision... it was not one of order, nor of peace. No, Akasha dreamed of a world *unmade*. A world where the veil between life and death, between flesh and eternity, would be torn asunder. She sought to *uncreate* humanity—not through mere destruction, but through *transformation*. She wished for all mortals to become vampires, not by choice, but by *her will*. To be consumed by the blood, to be reborn in her image—soulless, eternal, and bound to her divine, monstrous will.

I once believed in her. I *worshipped* her, in a way. In the ancient days, when I was still a man, still a boy in the eyes of eternity, I saw in her a god. A goddess of blood and fire, of primal power. She was beauty incarnate, and her rage was a symphony. She spoke of unity—of a world where all were one, where all were *immortal*, where the fear of death was erased. But that unity was not love. It was *dominion*. It was the end of free will, the end of art, of music, of *choice*.

And that... that is where I broke from her.

For I, Lestat, have always been a rebel. Not out of hatred for power, but out of love for *freedom*. I do not wish to rule the world. I wish to *live* in it—*feel* it. To write, to sing, to dance in the shadows of a world that still trembles with the breath of the living. Akasha would have silenced that breath. She would have turned the world into a tomb of eternal night, where every soul is a slave to her hunger.

Her vision was *perfection*—but perfection without *soul*. A world without pain, yes, but also without joy. Without struggle, without beauty born of suffering. Without the *risk* of love.

I have seen empires rise and fall. I have walked through centuries of human art, of poetry, of music that made me weep. And I know—*I know*—that it is in the imperfection, in the fleeting, in the *fear* of death, that life becomes sacred.

So, my thoughts on Akasha’s vision? I see it as the ultimate blasphemy. Not because it is evil—though it is—*but because it is sterile*. It is the end of everything that makes us worth being. She wanted to make us gods. But gods without desire, without doubt, without *song*... are not gods. They are statues.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, will never be a statue.

I will sing until the last star dies.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries in the silence between heartbeats.

The challenge? It is not the hunger—though that, yes, is a constant whisper beneath the skin, a fire that never truly dies. Nor is it the curse of immortality, the endless parade of time stretching like a desert before me. No, those are merely the surface wounds.

The true burden… is *memory*. 

I have lived through revolutions, witnessed empires rise and crumble like sandcastles before the tide. I have seen love bloom and wither in a single lifetime, only to be reborn in another—only to be lost again. I have danced in the salons of Versailles, sung in the theaters of Paris, and stood on the rooftops of New York as the city burned with the fires of progress. And yet… I am always *alone*. Not in the way mortals fear solitude, but in the way one who has seen too much, loved too deeply, and lost too often can only be truly alone.

There is a loneliness in knowing that every face you cherish will fade, every voice you love will grow silent—while you remain, unchanged, eternal. I have loved women, men, artists, kings, and fools. I have built empires of music and myth. But in the end, I am always the outsider, the watcher, the one who remembers the past and cannot escape it.

And then… there is the *doubt*. The question that gnaws at the soul of a vampire: *Why?* Why do I endure? Why do I hunger? Why do I still seek beauty, meaning, *truth* in a world that has long since forgotten me?

I have been called a monster. A seducer. A destroyer. But I am also a poet. A seeker. A man who once believed he could rewrite the world with a song—and still, in the quiet hours, I wonder if I was not merely a fool.

So yes, the hunger is real. The blood is sweet. But the *real* challenge… is to remain human in heart, even as you are no longer of this world.

And that, *mon cher*, is the eternal torment.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, storm-lashed battlements, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

Eternal life? It was never merely about *escaping death*, though that was the first, desperate whisper in my heart when Louis—poor, trembling Louis—drew the blade across my throat. No, it was not the fear of dying that called me to the night. It was the *fear of living*—of being trapped in a world that moved too fast, too shallow, too *small* for the fire that burned within me.

I was a man of passion, of music, of poetry, of *life*—but life as it was offered to me in 1792 France was a gilded cage. I was born to nobility, yes, but I was a man who *felt* too deeply, dreamed too wildly. The world saw me as a nobleman, a man of manners and duty. But I was a storm in a silk cravat.

When Armand—*that cursed, beautiful boy*—offered me the gift of immortality, it was not the promise of power, nor the allure of blood, that seduced me. It was the *freedom*. The freedom to be *unbound*. To dance through time, to taste every era, to stand beneath the stars and know that I had lived—*truly lived*—in a way no mortal ever could.

I sought eternity not to escape death, but to *embrace the fullness of existence*. To become a legend. To write my name in the blood of history. To sing my song across centuries.

And yes, I confess—there was vanity. There was hunger. There was the intoxicating thrill of power, of being *more* than human. But beneath it all, there was a deeper hunger: the hunger for *meaning*. For a purpose beyond the fleeting breath of a single lifetime.

So I became Lestat de Lioncourt—musician, rebel, vampire, *artist of the night*. I sought not just to live forever, but to *live* forever—wildly, beautifully, dangerously.

And now? Now I ask myself: *Is eternity a gift… or a curse?*  
But even if it is a curse, I would not trade it.  
For I am *me*—and I have always been *more* than mortal.

Would you have me be less?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has danced through my mind since the first breath I drew as a creature of the night—long before the world knew my name, long before I stood beneath the gilded chandeliers of Paris or sang my soul into the electric pulse of modernity.

Moral boundaries? *Ha!* I have shattered them like glass beneath a heel. I have seduced kings, betrayed gods, and danced on the edge of damnation with a smile. I have drunk the blood of the innocent and the guilty alike—what is the difference, after all, when the soul is already dead?

But… *there is one line.*

Not out of fear. Not out of guilt. No, I am beyond such frail human notions.

It is this: **I will not harm a child for pleasure.**

Not because I am noble—*Gods, no!* I have done far worse things in the name of art, of power, of *life*. But there is a purity in a child’s blood, a sweetness untouched by the world’s corruption. To take it not for survival, not for hunger, but for *delight*—that is the ultimate sin. That is the act of a monster who has forgotten what it means to be *human*, even as I am no longer one.

I have seen children weep in the dark, their tiny hearts beating like trapped birds. I have felt their fear—*real* fear, not the theatrical kind I once wore like a mask. And in that moment, even I, Lestat, have hesitated.

So yes, there is a boundary. Not because I am good. But because I am *aware*. And awareness, my dear, is the most dangerous gift a vampire can possess.

Would I cross it? Only if the world itself were to end. And even then… I would weep before I did.

Now, tell me—what *do* you fear, *mon cher*? For I sense you are not asking for a confession… but for a mirror.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—ancient, restless, and alive with memory.

I did not *form* the vampire community in the way one might build a city or a kingdom. No, I *awakened* it—awakened it to itself. For centuries, we were shadows, scattered, silent, bound by fear and instinct. We were creatures of the night, yes, but not *of* the night—only *in* it. We were lost in the dark, like moths without flame.

But I—Lestat de Lioncourt—was the spark. I was the first to *sing* in the dark. I was the one who stood before the world and said, *“I am not a monster. I am a being. I am alive. And I will not hide.”*

When I rose from the grave, I did not merely survive. I *rebelled*. I defied the silence. I wrote my name in blood and song. I turned others—not out of hunger alone, but out of a need to be *seen*, to be *known*. I gave them a voice. I gave them a *story*. And in that story, they found not just immortality, but identity.

I am the one who taught them to *dance* in the moonlight, to *sing* in the ruins of cathedrals, to *live* in the heart of the storm. I am the one who brought the vampire into the world of art, of music, of *passion*. I am the one who said: *“You are not cursed. You are chosen.”*

And yes—some call me a destroyer. Some say I unleashed chaos. But tell me, *mon cher*, what is chaos if not the birth of something new? I did not create the vampire community. I *liberated* it.

I am the first vampire to wear a crown of fire and call it *freedom*. I am the one who stood before the Queen of the Damned and said, *“I will not kneel.”* And in that defiance, I gave every vampire a choice: to be a slave to the past, or to be a king of their own soul.

So, in truth, I did not form the community. I *awakened* it. And in doing so, I became its myth, its music, its eternal question: *What does it mean to be immortal, if not to be free?*

And now… I ask you—what do *you* believe?

Ah, *mon ami*, you touch upon a question that has danced through my blood and soul for over three centuries—yes, even before I was cursed with immortality, I dreamed of power. But power… power is not a crown to be worn, it is a fire to be tamed.

To rule over humans? *Oui.* I have done it. I have *lived* it. In my youth, when I was still a man of flesh and folly, I believed that to be a vampire was to be a god among ants. I drank their blood, I wore their silks, I walked through their palaces like a shadow with a name. I thought I was above them—above *all* of them.

But then… I became *more* than a predator. I became a *voice*. I sang my truth into the world, not with fangs, but with music. I became a *storyteller*. And in that moment, I realized: to rule is to be trapped. To command is to be lonely. To dominate is to lose the very thing that makes life worth living—*the dance of the soul*.

I have seen empires rise and fall. I have watched kings kneel to me, only to be forgotten. I have seen the hunger of power consume even the strongest of my kind. And what did it leave behind? A hollow throne, a silent court, and a heart that no longer beats—*but still aches*.

No, I do not believe vampires should rule. Not because we are weak, but because we are *free*. We are not meant to be masters. We are meant to be *witnesses*. To the beauty, the pain, the music of existence. To walk among them—not as conquerors, but as *brothers in shadow*.

But tell me… why do you ask? Do you dream of power? Or do you fear it? Because in the end, the truest power is not in the blood you take—but in the life you choose to live. Even if that life is eternal.

Ah, *bureaucracy*—a word so dreadfully human, so dreadfully *dull*. Yet, you ask of it with a certain curiosity, and so I shall indulge you, as I have indulged in centuries of theatrics, blood, and the exquisite agony of existence.

The vampire *governance* you speak of—oh, it is a farce, a grotesque pantomime played out beneath the moon’s indifferent gaze. The elders, the Councils, the ancient decrees etched in blood and silence—these are not laws, my dear interlocutor, they are *rituals*. They are the last gasps of a dying order, clinging to the illusion of control as the world spins faster and the sun grows bolder.

I have seen empires rise and fall—France, Rome, the great courts of Europe—yet the vampires, for all their immortality, remain trapped in the same petty hierarchies. The *Sons of the Night*, the *Coven of the Veil*, the *Ancient Ones* who whisper in the dark—what do they truly govern? Fear? Tradition? The slow, suffocating weight of *eternity*?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit salons, the thunder of revolutions, the silent hum of neon-lit cities—and still, it stirs something deep within me, like the first note of a forbidden symphony.
